Etymology not certain, but Tai: S. prap⁴ ``to subdue, conquer'' is the same etymon and indicates a PCH form *praps > OCM *prâts. . The direction of borrowing is undetermined, yet Tai is prob. not the ultimate source of CH. More likely, the etymon is a ``medial r'' causative derivation  with the addition of the redundant exoactive final *-s

Perhaps connected with MK, but the OC medial *r poses a problem: MK *pɔɔk ``to peel''  ⇒ Tai: S. pɔɔkᴰ¹ ``to peel'' note also PTai *dlɔɔk: S. lɔɔkᴰ² ``to skin, peel'' ⪤ plɔɔkᴰ¹ ``an encasement, slipcover, sheath'' . This word is thought to be related to {lù₁ 彔} ``carve'', but ``carve'' and ``peel'' are rather different procedures

Lepcha bí ``edge, border'', lyaŋ bí ``utmost limit of a place'' WT pʰyi ``outside''  ⪤ pʰyin ``outside''. The wf {bǐ₁ 比} either belongs to the same root, or two ST roots: *pi ``edge, outside'' and *pi ``next to, follow, after'' have partially converged in CH and WT. In either case, these nouns would be n-nominalizations of a stem *pi

? Area word: Mru rak Kukish prak ``eldest brother'' LB-Lahu phâ ``god, lord'' < - Siam. pʰráʔ < - Khmer . Since Kuki-Chin languages have incorporated MK loans, this etymon may ultimately be AA. Among alternative proposals is derivation from {bái₁ 白} ``white'', hence bó ``the white-haired one'' , note the semantics of {pó₃ 皤} ``white > white-haired'' – but this is prob. a folk etymology

The etymology is not clear, perhaps the s. w. as {chā₁ 叉} ``fork'', lit. ``branch off'' > ``diverge'', but the semantic field of this wf points in a different direction Or perhaps AA: Khmer cāya /caaj/ ``give out, scatter, disperse'' ⪤ OKhmer /cŋaaj/ ``be separated, apart, far away, be different''

Misc: Sagart  suggests that chá is a loan from Loloish  *la ``leaf, tea'' PLB *s-la ``leaf / tea'' , as tea may have originated in Sìchuān this word has wider distribution, also in Zhuang  la⁴ means ``tea'', the ultimate source seems to be PAA *sla ``leaf''. Alternatively Qiu Xigui  considers ``tea'' with its bitter leaves a semantic extansion of tú 荼 ``name of a bitter plant''

Most likely, this old area word is related to Mru teŋ ``sacrificial tripod'' Wa-Lawa-Bulang *dɐŋ, *dɑŋ ``cooking pot''  Alternatively Benedict  connects this word with PT and PKS *gliaŋᴬ ``tripod'', perhaps related to Wa-Lawa-Bulang *klɐŋ ``basin'' PPalaung  geŋ ``tripod'' note also PTai *giŋᴬ ``tripod''. But these last forms present phonological difficulties

MY: The source of this word is apparently a form similar to Yao *bluŋ⁶ ``rain'' Wáng FS has PYao < PMY *mblɒəŋ⁶, but almost all individual Yao languages have a back vowel: blŭŋ⁶, bjŭŋ⁶, bŭŋ⁶, biŋ⁶ . Perh. ultimately related to the AA etymon under {píng₄ 萍} ``rain master'' note a back vowel form PEKatuic *piloŏŋ ``sky'', perhaps also Kharia tɔ-bluŋ ``above'' . MY back vowels tend to correspond to other languages’ front vowels and vice versa

Etymology not certain.  It could be a ST word: Kanauri luk ``calf'' WT lug ``sheep'', lu-gu ``lamb, calf'' TGTM *g-luk ``sheep''.  Boodberg  suggests cognation with WT pʰrug ``calf'' .  Alternatively, it could be a loan from Altaic acc. to Norman : Mongol tuɣul Manchu tukšan Evenki tukučə̄n ``calf'' Lamut tu- ~ tuɣu- ``to give birth to a calf''.  It could be related to {chù₄,xù 畜}. Dú may be connected with yú 羭
Sino_Tibetan_Cognates: Lamut	tu- ~ tuɣu-	``to give birth to a calf''

The first textual appearance in Chǔcí suggests a foreign word. MK has several roots with the meaning ``hill, mound'': MK *dul ``hill'' , and MK *bt1ul, *bt1uəl ``swelling, mound, hill'' OKhmer dul ``to bulge'' OKhmer /duuəl/ ``knoll, hillock, mound'' PVM *dolᴬ ``hill'' PSBahn. *tul ~ *nətul ``anthill''. Also MK *r ``hill'' . < > A similar looking Tai and MY etymon is probably not related because of the post-initial liquid: PTai *ʔdl/rɔiᴬ: S. dɔɔiᴬ¹ ``mountain'' Saek rɔɔyᴬ¹ PMY *glaɨᴰ ``mountain''

This word may be a cognate of {xū₄ 須鬚} ``beard'' . After labial initials, there has been some dialectal confusion of OC *-o  and *-ə    in the Shījīng, and this looks like a similar case which is strengthened by ér's use as a phonetic element in words with *-o  and *-on

Commentators, including SW, consider this etymon to be the s. w. as {fā 發} ``come out'', hence ``lift out / up'' . Alternatively, it may possibly be related to {fá₃ 伐罰} ``cut off, hew out'' and/or to {bá₂ 茇} ``roots of grass'' and id. ``to camp''

Lushai pumᴴ ``whole, all, everywhere'' WB pum ``form, model, pattern''. This word is usually thought related to Tai: S. pʰrɔɔmᶜ² ``together'' , but this is doubtful in light of the likely TB cognates without medial *r WT byibs < bibs ``shape, figure, form'' . Alternatively Yú Mǐn  related the CH word to WT babs ``shape, form, appearance''

Etymology not certain, perhaps ST: WT byaŋ-ba ``skill, experience'' ⪤ sbyoŋ-pa, sbyaŋs ``to train, exercise, study, learn, practice'' . Alternatively, the items may belong to AA: Khmer brāṅa /príiəŋ/ ``to represent the shape of, to sketch, design …'' < rāṅa /ríiəŋ/ ``body build, form, shape, figure'' if related, this group seems to belong to an AA wf which includes {zhuàng₁ 狀} ``form, shape''. ``Law, norm, standard'' etc. is a common semantic extension of ``form, shape, pattern'', cf. fǎ 法

The OC form is close to items found in various languages in the area, but the exact relationships are elusive due to the uncertainty of the PCH form and the sound-symbolic nature of the word: PVM *p-soːs > p-hoːc > poːc / pʰoːc ``lungs''. < > Tai: S. pɔɔtᴰ¹ᴸ < *pɨɔt ``lung''  ⪤ S. pʰɔɔtᴰ¹ ``breathe, inhale'' , prob. a CH loans

Prob. several distinct etyma have coalesced in this wf fēn and in {fěn 粉} ``flour'', but the various sources are phonologically and semantically ambiguous and difficult to disentan gle, as words of the shape LH pun and their possible outside relations have meanings ranging from sky - weather - clouds - mist - snow - hoarfrost to flour - dust. Any foreign syllable pə/un, pə/ur, pə/ul, as well as pan/r/l could correspond to LH pun

There are several possible etymologies : ST *pul: PKiranti pʰùl ``flour'' WB pʰun ``dust'' etc., see {fēn₂ 雰氛} item . —  Haudricourt / Strecker  believe that the CH word is a loan from PMY *mpanᴮ ``flour'' Sagart  argues the opposite. Both in MY and CH ``flour'' and {fēn₂ 雰氛} ``mist, hoarfrost'' may be cognate

PTB *-laŋ with animal prefix *s- or *k-: Mru klaŋ ``male'' Lushai tlaŋ ``male'' Mikir chè-lóŋ ``buffalo'' WT glaŋ ``ox'' , glaŋ-po-čʰe  ``elephant''. Wáng Lì  relates this word to {gǔ₃ 牯} ``male of bovine, steer'', as well as to the wf {jiā₈ 豭} ``boar'', therefore gǔ 羖 meant originally ``male animal''. However, jiā and gǔ differ in MC vowel and tone, therefore gǔ prob. means basical ly ``ram'' and is cognate to {jié₄ 羯} ``ram''

SW implies that jiǎo is related to {jiāo₁ 交} ``cross'', i.e. a pyre of crossed logs, but the semantic connection with ``crossed'' may be due to the graphic element. TB cognates suggest that jiǎo actually means ``dry over fire, burn'': WB kro ~ kyo ``to fry'' JP krau³³ ``dry up, overdry'' ⪤ kə³¹-rau³³ ``dry over a fire''

The several words for ``comb'' in CH and TB look somewhat similar, but precise phonological correspondences are elusive. Jié appears to be close to PTB *m-si ``comb''  > JP pə⁵⁵-si⁵⁵ ``comb, rake'' ⪤ məsìt ``to comb, rake, brush'' Mikir iŋtʰi < msi ``comb'' Lepcha pŭr-šit  ``brush'' . Although an additional final consonant like -t here is not unusual for CH, the initials are rather different

Because of *ku's onomatopoetic nature there are variant forms in ST, some with medial -r-, some without: PTB *kuw  ``dove'' > Miri pəkü Meithei kʰu-nu, ``pigeon'' PTB *m-krəw: PLB *N-kruw² > WB kʰui ~ kʰyui ~ kʰrui Kuki *m-kʰru > Khami iŋ məkʰru. The Tai word looks like a loan from a Yuè dialect, yet PTai also had a medial *-r-: S. khauᴬ¹ < *khr-, *hr- ``dove''

Jū is the same etymon as {gǒu 狗} ``puppy dog'' acc. to Wáng Lì however, gǒu which comes from a non-ST language, is not a homophone of jū. It is more likely that jū is cognate to PTB *ku or *kor ``horse''  in Monpa kur-ta < ku-rta ``horse'' Tani *kɯ JP kum-ra < ku-mra ``horse'' Lushai saᴸ-kɔrᴿ ``a horse, pony'' Mru kor-ŋa

This etymon is often considered to be related to PTB *riy ``draw, paint, write, delimit'' etc.  > Lushai riᴿ ``boundary, frontier, limit, line of demarcation'' NNaga *rəy ``thread, boundary'', and WT ’bri-ba, bris ``to draw, write'' ⪤ ris ``figure'' WB reᴮ ``write, delineate, paint'' Mru pri ``to scratch'' . However, OC *ə corresponds normally to PTB *a, only rarely, if ever, to *i

Etymology not clear.  A loan from KT: PTai *r-: S. raaᴬ² ``we two '' Shan ha ``we two'' Lü hra ``I'' PKS *hra¹ ``two''. Li F.  associates the Tai word with CH {yú₅ 余} ``I'' for which he reconstructs OC *rag .  Cognate to PTB *s-raŋ > WT sraŋ ``pair of scales, weight''.  Finally, {shuāng₁ 雙} may be a derivation, but the vowels do not agree

PTB *rap  > KN-Lushai rapᴸ / raʔᴸ ``to tread , trample upon'' WT skrab-pa ``to stamp , tread'' ⪤ ’kʰrab-pa ``to strike, stump, thump''. However, the initial k- in the WT cognates skrab, ’kʰrab  could theoretically derive from an earlier initial *ʔ-, note the initial *ʔr- in the putative OC cognate {yā₃ 壓} OC *ʔrap ``press down, stamp'', as well as the absence of velar initials in the other TB languages perhaps also connected with dié 蹀  ``to trample, stamp''  , and possibly also to {niè₇ 躡} OC *nrap ``trample''

MY: PMiao *qɭeŋᴬ  ``ghost''. ``Ghost'' and {líng₈ 霝零} ``rain'' are etymologically distinct, although in the meaning ``prayer for rain, rainmaster'', the two converge. On the other hand, weather phenomena are divine portents, see {fēn₂ 雰氛}

Misc: Baxter  derives ``rule'' from the same root as {bǐ₆ 筆} ``brush, writing pencil'', both deriving from the notion ``draw a line, ruler'' but see bǐ  for an alternative etymology KN-Lushai hruaiᴴ < hruai ``to lead, guide, conduct'' Lai hruaj / hruaʔj ``to lead'' NNaga *ruaːy. Although this KN etymon looks suggestively similar to CH, the KN final -uaj is rather different from the OC final, perhaps in OC some vocalic levelling had taken place after the addition of the final -t

Míng 銘 is commonly thought to be related to {míng₁ 名}, but the semantic link is not compelling. Phonologically, this word agrees with WT byaŋ-ma / -bu ``inscription, direction, label, tablet'' for OC *m- = WT b-, see {§5.12.2} for OC *-e- = WT -ya-, see {§11.3.2}

Commentators explain that míng ``ocean'' is the s. w. as {míng₂ 冥} ``dark, black''  . There is an outside chance, though, that the etymon is instead connected with PTB *mlik > OBurm. mlac ``river'' WB -mrac Arakanese mreik ``sea'' SChin-Daai mlik  ``big water, river, sea''

GY makes a phonetic distinction between {mián₁ 瞑} ``sleep''  and míng 瞑 ``close eyes'' and treats these as two separate words. This is not an example of an occasional *-ŋ ~ *-n variation because ST *-l is not known to show up as CH -ŋ
Sino_Tibetan_Cognates: WB	distinguishes hminᴮ	``have the eyes shut''

ST, perhaps two parallel stems are involved: *mlak: KN-Khyang amlak Khami-Awa la’ ``to love'' SChin Daai mhlä ``to like, love'' . < > Tai: S. mak, ma-lak ``to love, cherish'' Saek makᴰ² ``to like, be fond of'' Wáng Lì  relates this wf to {fǔ₁₀ 撫} ``lay hands on, soothe'' . Forms like rak ``love'' in Tai and AA lgs. derive from Indic rāga ``passion''

Nà prob. belongs to demonstratives in non-ST languages, note especially PAA *na ``this'' a “very frequent type” in AA : Khmuʔ naa ``3rd person pronoun'' Khmer nai  ``there'' Munda na, naa ``this'' also Viet ṇo ``this'' . KT forms are not as close to CH: Tai: S. niiᶜ² < *n- ``this'' S. nanᶜ² < *n- ``that'' Nung nayᶜ² Wuming naiᶜ² etc. ``this''

Misc: WB paiᶜ ``broken off, chipped, hare-lipped'' ⪤ pʰaiᶜ break off in small pieces’ Dhimal bai ``break'' Lushai peʔᴸ < pes ``to break, be broken'' JP pʰjai³³ ``break'' ⪤ pʰjeʔ⁵⁵ < pʰjek⁵⁵ ``break'', also JP bjak³¹ ``break''. Sino_Tibetan_Cognates: OKhmer	pak /ak/	``to break, come or fall apart, separate, give way''

Misc: Pò ``soul'' is the same word as {pò₅ 霸魄} ``aspect of the moon''. With the first development of a foetus grows the vegetative soul jì shēng pò 既生魄 , the same phrase is used for phases of the moon. Pò, the soul responsible for growth, is the same as pò the waxing and waning of the moon

Pò ``soul'' is the same word as {pò₅ 霸魄} ``aspect of the moon''. With the first development of a foetus grows the vegetative soul jì shēng pò 既生魄 , the same phrase is used for phases of the moon. Pò, the soul responsible for growth, is the same as pò the waxing and waning of the moon
This is the same word as {pò₄ 魄} and cognate to {bái₁ 白} ``white'' TB languages also associate ``moon'' with ``white''

Sound-symbolic area word: PTB *syip ~ *syup  > WT šub-pa ~ šib-pa ``to whisper'', from a root *syup ~ *syip . But the CH item more closely resembles MK with its pre-initial: MK *ksip ``whisper'' : PMonic *ksap in chime words for whispering, e.g. Nyah-Kur kəchiaw- ``to whisper'' Khmer khsɨpa /ksỳp/ ``to whisper, murmur'' ⪤ /rsỳp/ ``be whispered, audible only as low murmur''. MK ⇒ Tai: S. krasípᴰ²-krasâapᴰ²

WT skyibs  ``a shelter from above'' prob. also cognate to NNaga *ciup ``roof'' One of the sources of WT sk- has been shown to be *s-ʔ- the etymon is therefore derived from ST *ʔip: WT yib ``eaves, shed'' ⪤ yib-pa ``to hide oneself, place of concealment'' Lushai uupᶠ ``be sheltered from wind, free from draughts''
Sino_Tibetan_Cognates: Lushai	uupᶠ	``be sheltered from wind, free from draughts''

Early coins had the shapes of spades and knives therefore qián is a derivation from jiǎn . Alternatively Boltz  explains qián as ``a fragment, token'' Wáng Shèngměi  considers qián derived from {qiǎn₂ 淺} ``shallow'' > ``thin''
Sino_Tibetan_Cognates: Boltz	explains qián as	``a fragment, token''

Etymology not clear.  The word could perhaps be  a k-prefix concrete noun derived from {yīn₅ 陰} ``overcast'', i.e. ``covered'' . Comparanda may include: WB kʰrum ~ kʰyum ``cover, overspread'' WT grum-če ``thick woolen blanket'' .  WT kʰyim ``house''  which is derived from TB *im but see {yì₈ 邑}

Misc: Since OC final *-n can have several sources , a TB cognate is difficult to identify: Bodman  relates this wf to WT kʰyor ``a handful'' ⪤ ’kʰyor ``to warp'', or WT ’kʰor ``circle''.  Or note Lushai kʰɔɔrᴿ ``double up, roll up''.  Or Lushai kualᴸ ``to coil''.  Or perhaps cognate to Lushai hrualᴴ ``roll up in the hand''.  These could be n-suffixed forms of {gōu₁ 句鉤枸區}. The OC vowel *o, as in *noʔ, often corresponds to foreign *u in open syllables . On the other hand, *noʔ also looks like a regular endoactive derivation  from {rú₄ 懦臑} *no ``soft'', lit. ``the thing that is soft'', a possible re-etymologization of the area word PTB *nuw ~ *now  > WT nu-ma ``breast'' ⪤ nu-ba ``to suck'' ⪤ nud-pa ``to suckle'' Tsangla nu ``milk'' Lushai hnuᴸ-teᴿ < hnuʔ/h ``breast, milk'' ⪤ nuᶠ < nuuʔ ``mother, married woman'' PLB *no³, WB nuiᶜ JP nu⁵¹ ``mother, mother's sister'' etc. JP gə³¹-nu³¹ ``mother''. < > Perh. an area word: Kharia Mundari nunu ``female breast'' ⪤ Mundari nu ``to drink'' Wa-Lawa-Bulang *ɲɨʔ PVM *ɲuːʔ ``drink''

Most likely, this is a final -t derivation  from a ST root *nwe: WB nweᴮ, hnweᴮ ``warm'' Lai nwê ``be warm'' or, less likely, from {ráo₂ 蕘} ``fuel''. There are parallels for the medial-vowel metathesis, see {něi 餒}, {shuāi 衰}

Since this word's source is Qí in Shandong which is believed to have been inhabited by AA speakers down to early historic times , it may be AA: Kharia sɔmɔŋ Munda samaŋ ``forehead'', possibly connected with the root OKhmer saṅ /sɔŋ/ ``to raise'', since other words for ``forehead'' are derived from the notion ``lift, high''

This word belongs to a widespread SE Asian assemblage of etyma for ``wink, blink'', including PAN sap ``winnow'' K-Méixiàn sap⁷ ``wink'' Y-Hongkong saap⁷ ``id''. For an exhaustive collection and treatment, see R. Bauer LTBA 15.2: 151-184

Prob. AA: MMon salah ``to give away, disburse'' A superior person giving something to an inferior is the basic meaning of this wf, whereas the root from which it is prob. derived, {yǔ₉ 與}, means ``to give'' in general. The etyma *lhaʔ ~ *lhai  are prob. variants

The OC pair derives from a ST doublet *s-njap ~ *r-njap: PTB *s/r-nyap ``pinch, squeeze''  > WT rñab-rñab-pa ``to seize or snatch together'' Chepang nep- ``press together uniformly …'' Mikir nép ``to catch'' PLB *nyap > WB ñap ``be pinched, squeezed between'' ⪤ hñap ``to squeeze, press between two objects'', in Lolo lgs. also ``shoes'' . CH ⇒ Tai: S. nɛɛpᴰ¹ᴸ < *hn- ``pincers, to hold''

The OC initial *n- has been suggested by Unger  because of shěn and possible cognation with {nǎn₂ 揇}. If the OC initial was indeed *n-, then the following TB items are related: PTB *nem : WB nim ``be low'' ⪤ nim ``be kept low, below'' Lushai hniamᴿ ``be low, sink into''  ⪤ hnimᴴ ``dip into'' tr. Tankhul Naga kʰənim ``be humble'' WT nems ``sink a little, give way''

ST terminative final *-ŋ derivation  from ST *sri ``to be, exist'', hence lit. ``come into existence > give birth > live'': PTB *s-riŋ   > Manchati sriŋ ``to live, alive'' Lushai hriŋᴴ / hrinᴸ ``fresh, green'' ⪤ hriŋᴴ / hrinᴿ ``bear, beget'' NNaga *C-riŋ  ``alive'' Chepang sriŋ- ``open out'' , begin to blossom’ Mikir reŋᴸ ``live, come to life'' JP tsiŋ³³ < rjiŋ  ``weeds, rank grass'' NNaga *C/V-criŋ ``raw, grass'' . With vowel *a: WB hraŋ ``live, alive''

This word is often related to {tīng₂ 聽} ``hear''  in which case OCM would be *lheŋh. Formally, it looks like a derivation from {shēng₅ 聲} ``sound'', in which case it would be OCM *hjeŋh and literally mean ``be renowned, one who is renowned''

The OC form and etymology are a matter of conjecture: Unger  reconstructs this word with an OC nasal initial he bases this on the Shìmíng   gloss xū 須 < *sn-, and the GY graph 杽 for QYS ṇjəuᴮ ~ ṭʰjəuᴮ 杻 . He suggests that shǒu is cogn. to {niǔ₁ 狃丑} ``finger''.  Alternatively, shǒu may be derived from {shōu 收} ``take, gather'', tone B would then be the endoactive morpheme: ``hand'' < lit. ``the thing that is doing the taking''

AA has a similar-looking word: Khmer /ríiəw/ ``diminish, decrease, taper , slim slender …'' ⪤ /srìiəw/ ``be small-boned and slender'', but the diphthong is the reverse of CH perhaps a metathesis from *-iu to *-ui took place in OC . An alternative comparandum may be Lushai zuaiᶠ < juaiʔ ``decline'' , but Lushai initial z- usually derives from PTB *y-, and the semantic agreement is not as close

Since both CH and WT have a word for ``sleep'' which is nearly homophonous with one for ``droop'', it is probable that shuì is derived from {chuí₁ 垂} *doi ``droop''. The WT cognate seems to be yur-ba ``to slumber'' ⪤ g-yur ``sleep''  ⪤ g-yur-ba ``droop, hang or sink down'' , but phonologically, the OC items are closer to a parallel stem in rime *-ol, see {chuí₁ 垂}

Misc: Perh. PTB *gliŋ ``ground, land, country, region'': NNaga *C/v-khliŋ ``place'' WT gliŋ ``island, continent''. In a round-about way, this etymon might have entered the language of the ancient state of Chǔ during the Han period where we find tīng 汀  LH tʰeŋ ``island'' if true, the word must have been written down at a time  when OC *hl- and *th- had merged into tʰ-

Karlgren  relates this word to {tóng₁ 同} ``to join'' but metals are typically associated with color, therefore the word is probably related to tóng 彤 ``red''  . The word ``copper'' occurs in some SE Asian languages with initial l-: Tai-Wuming luːŋ² Palaung məlɔŋ ``copper''

The late appearance of tóu in the 6th cent BC when it began to replace {shǒu₃ 首} suggests that it is derived from the much earlier attested vessel {dòu₂ 豆} , but dòu  looks like a derivation from tóu instead which may therefore originally have meant ``skull''. An allofam may be {dòu₃ 荳} ``bean''

Perhaps ST *ur: Lushai urʔᴸ ``to burn'' , ``get smoky'', uurᴴ ``to smoke, to heat, distill; to warm'' ⪤ uutᶠ / uʔ ``to burn, char, scorch'' ⪤ urᴴ roᴴ ``to dry'' Mikir ur ``to dry over the fire'' . However, while the TB items tend to imply burning and fire, a homophonous MK etymon is semantically closer to OC: MK *cʔur, *cʔuur  ``warm'' : Stieng uːr ``to heat '' Khasi ur ``with a warm sensation''. Prob. not  related to {yù₂₀,yǔ 嫗} ST *ʔo

PTB *s-rak  ``spend the night, full day and night, 24 hrs''  > WT žag < ryak ``day'' Kanauri hrak ``day'' Lahul gyag ``day'' Lepcha ayak ``day'' PLB *ʔrak > WB rak, ə-rak ``a complete day of 24 hrs.'' Lahu há ``spend the night'', ɔ̀-há ``night'' Lushai riakᶠ / riaʔᴸ ``put up for the night, stay the night'' JP yaʔ⁵⁵ < yak⁵⁵ ``day'' Limbu yaːkt- ``to stay'' . CH preinitial *s- for other languages’ *r- and vice versa is not uncommon, see {§5.3}

Xī has several possible etymologies.  Because 西 appears to be the phonetic in the graph nǎi 迺  *nə̂ʔ, some investigators assume an OC *sn- cluster. Unger  relates xī to WT ner-ba ``to sink, go down'' or  it is related instead to Chepang nelʔ- ``go down, set''  .  A MK nominal n-infix derivative from the root ``go down'' as in OMon cnis ``ghat'' < cis ``go down'' , with PAA *tsn- > PCH *sn-, see {§2.6.1}

This word *sak is prob. cognate to {xī₁ 夕} *s-jak ``evening'' . They look like variants of the same PCH or ST form *s-jak  ``24 hr. period'' in 昔 the *s- was treated like the root initial, in 夕 it was treated like a prefix this bifurcation with doublets occurs also in roots which have initial *j- and pre-initial *r-, see {§9.2.1}

Misc: This word is usually considered the same as {xiàng₅ 象} ``elephant, ivory'' > `` image, resemble'' , but ivory was not the only sculpture material. Although the OC initial in ``elephant'' was probably not L-like OCB *z- and *s-l- / *s-j- might have merged in the Zuǒzhuàn if so, xiàng ``image'' may possibly derive from a ST root *la: WT lad-mo ``imitation, to imitate, mimic'' WT lha ``gods, image of a deity'' Lepcha klan ``similar'' ⪤ klan-lă ``imitation'' JP sum³¹-la³³ ``picture, image'', num³¹-la³³ ``ghost''

Misc: Etymology not clear. Similar-looking words in other languages are unrelated Lushai ziakᶠ / ziaʔᴸ < jak / jaks ``to write, draw, inscribe, engrave'' Lushai lehk’a  is a Pali loan WB ca ``writing, document'' JP tʃa³³ ``paint, daub, dye'' . Acc. to FY 6, xū is a Wú-Yuè dial. word for ``assist'', which is prob. derived from ``mutual'' as in the parallel and cognate wf {xiāng₁ 相} . The Han period  association with the language of Wú and Yuè  seems to strengthens the possibility that this is originally a MK etymon: Pearic saː ``each other''

Misc: Etymology not certain, yě may have one of two possible etymological connections.  ST: In Tibet and the Himalayas exists a common word *la which originally might have referred to an area far from settlements, i.e. ``wilderness'': WT la ``mountain pass, hillside, mountain slope'' SWTib.: Dzongkha Gloskad laᴸ ``mountain'' Western Tib.: Zangskar la ``border, frontier'' Kanauri: Pat. lha Kaike la ``mountain'' Tamang lah²¹ ``hill'' Or  the word belongs to the same AA root to which also belongs {yì₃₅ 繹}: OKhmer lā  ``to open, unfold, extend …'' ⪤ dalā  ``to be open, extensive, broad'' PMonic *lah > OMon ``to extend'' > Mod. Mon ``be level, flat, extensive''

PTB *ya ``night''  > Chepang yaʔ-diŋ ``night'', yoh ``yesterday'', yoh-dyah-may ``last night'' WB ñaᶜ ``evening'' < ne-ja ``sun-night'' JP naʔ⁵⁵ < nak⁵⁵ ``evening'' Dulong ɉɑʔ ``night'' Karen hja . Lushai zaanᴸ ~ zanᶠ < jaŋ  ``night'', niᶠ-zaanᴸ < jaanh < jaans ``last night'' Areng  jaŋ ``yesterday'' Limbu yaːn ``day''  . {xī₁ 夕} is usually thought to be cognate, but TB keeps the etyma ST *rjak ``24 hrs., day, night'' and *ja ``night'' strictly separate, and there is no reason why this should not be done in OC

A widely distributed phonaesthetic etymon in East and SE Asia, including AN, with the rime *-ap and initial *r-, *l-,*w-,*j- etc., often with pre-syllables . The L-initial variant is widely encountered in the area: PTB *s-lyap WT lhab-lhab-pa, lhab-se-lhabs ``to flutter to and fro, to glimmer, glisten'' Lepcha lyóp  ``flap'' Adi lip-lop ``to flash'' WB lyap-lyap ``wavingly '' ⪤ hlyap ``lightning'' Lushai inᴸ-hlapᴴ ``to flick, flap'' JP prap⁵⁵ ``a flash''. < > KT: Siam. lɛɛpᴰ²ᴸ ~ ma-lɛɛp ``to flash'' PHlai ɬjip⁷ ``lightning''

Value: either jap or wap or both

Misc: The basic meaning of the PTB root *lam ``to trample'' raises the possibility that this is its OC cognate: Tiddim Chin laamᴹ / laamᶠ ``to dance'' ⪤ lamᴿ ``way, road'' Lai laam / laʔm ``to trample, dance'' WT ’čʰam-pa < ɴ-lhyam ``to dance'' ⪤ lam ``path, road''. The latter ``path, road'' is derivable from the meaning ``to trample''

This etymon agrees phonologically with WT skyiŋ-ser ``eagle, vulture'' , if one assumes derivation from *s-ʔyiŋ. Alternatively, in spite of the difference in the initials, yīng is widely held to be related to a ubiquitous area word: PMK *knleeŋ ``hawk'' or *klaaŋ ``bird of prey, hawk, eagle''  > Khm klɛŋ PMonic *liŋ-liəŋ ``hawk'' Mon kəniə̯ŋ ``kite'' . PTB *g-laŋ  > WB laŋᴮ-taᶜ ``vulture'' Kachin laŋ ``bird of the falcon family'' Garo do-reŋ ``falcon, kite'' Bodo dau-laŋ-a ``eagle'' Dimasa dau-liŋ ``kite''

This word is prob. derived from one or other root *wan ``round, encircle'' , semantically like yuàn 院瑗 ``wall round courtyard'' , see {yíng₄ 營}. Therefore, the following are unrelated: KN-Kom ra-hụn ``garden'' Khmer swna /sùuən/ ``care for, look after > flower / pleasure garden''  ⇒ KT *swjaan  > S. suanᴬ¹ ``garden''

Bodman  relates this to Viet. giâý PVM *k-cajʔ  ``paper'' which, like the PMin form *tšiɑiᴮ, presupposes an OC rime *-ai rather than the QY's *-e. When this word was committed to writing, the rimes OC *-ai and *e had already merged in some dialects, a process which is observed already in late Zhou texts
